HENRY POWELL BARTLEY]37-mrs . henry powell bartley : Permit [me]0-i to add [your]37-mrs . henry powell bartley name to [my]0-i name , in publishing this novel . The pen which has written [my]0-i books can not be more agreeably employed than in acknowledging what [I]0-i owe to the pen which has skillfully and patiently helped [me]0-i , by copying [my]0-i manuscripts for the printer . First Period : 1858 - 1859 . EVENTS IN [THE PRISON]147-the prison , RELATED BY [THE GOVERNOR]148-the governor . CHAPTER I. [THE GOVERNOR]148-the governor EXPLAINS . At the request of [a person who has claims on [me]0-i that [I]0-i must not disown]150-a person who has claims on me that i must not disown , [I]0-i consent to look back through a long interval of years and to describe events which took place within the walls of [an English prison]151-an english prison during the earlier period of [my]0-i appointment as [Governor]152-governor . Viewing [my]0-i task by the light which later experience casts on it , [I]0-i think [I]0-i shall act wisely by exercising some control over the freedom of [my]0-i pen . [I]0-i propose to pass over in silence the name of [the town in which is situated [the prison]147-the prison once confided to [my]0-i care]153-the town in which is situated the prison once confided to my care . [I]0-i shall observe a similar discretion in alluding to [individuals]155-individuals - some dead , [some living]156-some living , at the present time . Being obliged to write of [a woman who deservedly suffered the extreme penalty of the law]157-a woman who deservedly suffered the extreme penalty of the law , [I]0-i think [she]157-a woman who deservedly suffered the extreme penalty of the law will be sufficiently identified if [I]0-i call [her]157-a woman who deservedly suffered the extreme penalty of the law [The Prisoner]158-the prisoner . Of [the four persons present on the evening before [her]157-a woman who deservedly suffered the extreme penalty of the law execution]159-the four persons present on the evening before her execution three may be distinguished one from the other by allusion to [their]159-the four persons present on the evening before her execution vocations in life . [I]0-i here introduce [them]159-the four persons present on the evening before her execution as [The Chaplain]160-the chaplain , [The Minister]161-the minister , and [The Doctor]162-the doctor . [The fourth]163-the fourth was [a young woman]164-a young woman . [She]164-a young woman has no claim on [my]0-i consideration ; and , when [she]164-a young woman is mentioned , [her]164-a young woman name may appear . If these reserves excite suspicion , [I]0-i declare beforehand that they influence in no way the sense of responsibility which commands [an honest man]165-an honest man to speak the truth . CHAPTER II . [THE MURDERESS ASKS QUESTIONS]166-the murderess asks questions . The first of the events which [I]0-i must now relate was the conviction of [The Prisoner]158-the prisoner for the murder of [[her]158-the prisoner husband]168-her husband . [They]169-they had lived together in matrimony for little more than two years . [The husband]170-the husband , [a gentleman by birth and education]171-a gentleman by birth and education , had mortally offended [[his]170-the husband relations]172-his relations in marrying [a woman of an inferior rank of life]173-a woman of an inferior rank of life . [He]170-the husband was fast declining into a state of poverty , through [his]170-the husband own reckless extravagance , at the time when [he]170-the husband met with [his]170-the husband death at [[his]170-the husband wife]174-his wife 's hand . Without attempting to excuse [him]170-the husband , [he]170-the husband deserved , to [my]0-i mind , some tribute of regret . It is not to be denied that [he]170-the husband was profligate in [his]170-the husband habits and violent in [his]170-the husband temper . But it is equally true that [he]170-the husband was affectionate in the domestic circle , and , when moved by wisely applied remonstrance , sincerely penitent for sins committed under temptation that overpowered [him]170-the husband . If [[his]170-the husband wife]174-his wife had killed [him]170-the husband in a fit of jealous rage - under provocation , be it remembered , which [the witnesses]176-the witnesses proved - [she]174-his wife might have been convicted of manslaughter , and might have received a light sentence . But the evidence so undeniably revealed deliberate and merciless premeditation , that the only defense attempted by [[her]174-his wife counsel]177-her counsel was madness , and the only alternative left to [a righteous jury]178-a righteous jury was a verdict which condemned [the woman]179-the woman to death . [Those mischievous members of [the community , whose topsy - turvy sympathies]181-the community , whose topsy - turvy sympathies feel for [the living criminal]182-the living criminal and forget [the dead victim]183-the dead victim]180-those mischievous members of the community , whose topsy - turvy sympathies feel for the living criminal and forget the dead victim , attempted to save [her]179-the woman by means of high - flown petitions and contemptible correspondence in the newspapers . But [the Judge]184-the judge held firm ; and [the Home Secretary]185-the home secretary held firm . [They]186-they were entirely right ; and [the public]187-the public were scandalously wrong . [Our Chaplain]188-our chaplain endeavored to offer the consolations of religion to [the condemned wretch]189-the condemned wretch . [She]174-his wife refused to accept [his]170-the husband ministrations in language which filled [him]170-the husband with grief and horror . On the evening before the execution , [the reverend gentleman]190-the reverend gentleman laid on [my]0-i table [his]190-the reverend gentleman own written report of a conversation which had passed between [the Prisoner]158-the prisoner and [himself]190-the reverend gentleman . " [I]190-the reverend gentleman see some hope , [sir]3443-sir , "[190-the reverend gentleman] [he]190-the reverend gentleman said , " of inclining the heart of [this woman]3444-this woman to religious belief , before it is too late . Will [you]3443-sir read [my]190-the reverend gentleman report , and say if [you]3443-sir agree with [me]190-the reverend gentleman ? "[190-the reverend gentleman] [I]0-i read it , of course . It was called " [A Memorandum]3445-a memorandum , "[190-the reverend gentleman] and was thus written : " At [his]170-the husband last interview with [the Prisoner]158-the prisoner , [the Chaplain]160-the chaplain asked [her]158-the prisoner if [she]158-the prisoner had ever entered [a place of public worship]3448-a place of public worship . [She]158-the prisoner replied that [she]158-the prisoner had occasionally attended the services at [a Congregational Church in [this town]3450-this town]3449-a congregational church in this town ; attracted by the reputation of [the Minister]161-the minister as [a preacher]3452-a preacher . ' [He]161-the minister entirely failed to make [a Christian of [me]190-the reverend gentleman]3453-a christian of me , ' [she]158-the prisoner said ; ' but [I]190-the reverend gentleman was struck by [his]161-the minister eloquence . Besides , [he]161-the minister interested [me]190-the reverend gentleman personally - [he]161-the minister was [a fine man]3454-a fine man . ' "[190-the reverend gentleman] In the dreadful situation in which [the woman]179-the woman was placed , such language as this shocked [the Chaplain]160-the chaplain ; [he]160-the chaplain appealed in vain to [the Prisoner]158-the prisoner 's sense of propriety . ' [You]160-the chaplain do n't understand [women]195-women , ' [she]179-the woman answered . ' [The greatest saint of [my]0-i sex that ever lived]196-the greatest saint of my sex that ever lived likes to look at [a preacher]3452-a preacher as well as to hear [him]3452-a preacher . If [he]3452-a preacher is [an agreeable man]198-an agreeable man , [he]3452-a preacher has all the greater effect on [her]196-the greatest saint of my sex that ever lived . [This preacher]199-this preacher 's voice told [me]0-i [he]3452-a preacher was kind - hearted ; and [I]0-i had only to look at [his]3452-a preacher beautiful eyes to see that [he]3452-a preacher was trustworthy and true . ' " It was useless to repeat a protest which had already failed . Recklessly and flippantly as [she]179-the woman had described it , an impression had been produced on [her]179-the woman . It occurred to [the Chaplain]160-the chaplain that [he]160-the chaplain might at least make the attempt to turn this result to [her]179-the woman own religious advantage . [He]160-the chaplain asked whether [she]179-the woman would receive [the Minister]161-the minister , if [the reverend gentleman]190-the reverend gentleman came to [the prison]147-the prison . ' That will depend , ' [she]200-she said , ' on whether [you]160-the chaplain answer some questions which [I]200-she want to put to [you]160-the chaplain first . ' [The Chaplain]160-the chaplain consented ; provided always that [he]160-the chaplain could reply with propriety to what [she]200-she asked of [him]160-the chaplain . [Her]200-she first question only related to [himself]160-the chaplain . "[200-she] [She]200-she said : ' [The women who watch [me]0-i]201-the women who watch me tell [me]0-i that [you]202-you are [a widower]203-a widower , and have [a family of children]204-a family of children . Is that true ? ' " [The Chaplain]160-the chaplain answered that it was quite true . "[200-she] [She]200-she alluded next to a report , current in [the town]205-the town , that [the Minister]161-the minister had resigned [the pastorate]207-the pastorate . Being personally acquainted with [him]161-the minister , [the Chaplain]160-the chaplain was able to inform [her]200-she that [his]161-the minister resignation had not yet been accepted . On hearing this , [she]200-she seemed to gather confidence . [Her]200-she next inquiries succeeded each other rapidly , as follows : " ' Is [[my]200-she handsome preacher]3461-my handsome preacher married ? ' "[200-she] ' Yes . ' " ' Has [he]161-the minister got [any children]3462-any children ? ' "[200-she] ' [He]161-the minister has never had [any children]3462-any children . ' " ' How long has [he]161-the minister been married ? ' "[200-she] ' As well as [I]0-i know , about seven or eight years . " ' What sort of woman is [[his]161-the minister wife]174-his wife ? ' " ' Is [[her]210-a lady husband]168-her husband well off ? ' "[161-the minister] ' [He]161-the minister has a sufficient income . ' " After that reply , [the Prisoner]158-the prisoner 's curiosity appeared to be satisfied . [She]211-she said , ' Bring [[your]158-the prisoner friend]3466-your friend [the preacher]3467-the preacher to [me]211-she , if [you]158-the prisoner like ' - and there it ended . "[211-she] What [her]211-she object could have been in putting these questions , it seems to be impossible to guess . Having accurately reported all that took place , [the Chaplain]160-the chaplain declares , with heartfelt regret , that [he]160-the chaplain can exert no religious influence over [this obdurate woman]213-this obdurate woman . [He]160-the chaplain leaves it to [the Governor]148-the governor to decide whether [the Minister of the Congregational Church]215-the minister of the congregational church may not succeed , where [the Chaplain of [the Jail]217-the jail]216-the chaplain of the jail has failed . Herein is the one last hope of saving the soul of [the Prisoner]158-the prisoner , now under sentence of death ! " In those serious words the Memorandum ended . Although not personally acquainted with [the Minister]161-the minister [I]148-the governor had heard of [him]161-the minister , on all sides , as [an excellent man]3469-an excellent man . In the emergency that confronted [us]3470-us [he]161-the minister had , as it seemed to [me]148-the governor , [his]161-the minister own sacred right to enter [the prison]147-the prison ; assuming that [he]161-the minister was willing to accept , what [I]148-the governor [myself]148-the governor felt to be , a very serious responsibility . The first necessity was to discover whether [we]3470-us might hope to obtain [his]161-the minister services . With [my]148-the governor full approval [the Chaplain]160-the chaplain left [me]148-the governor , to state the circumstances to [[his]160-the chaplain reverend colleague]3473-his reverend colleague . CHAPTER III . [THE CHILD]3474-the child APPEARS . During [[my]148-the governor friend]3475-my friend 's absence , [my]148-the governor attention was claimed by a sad incident - not unforeseen . It is , [I]148-the governor suppose , generally known that [near relatives]3476-near relatives are admitted to take [their]3476-near relatives leave of [criminals condemned to death]3477-criminals condemned to death . In the case of [the Prisoner now waiting for execution]3478-the prisoner now waiting for execution , [no person]3479-no person applied to [the authorities]3480-the authorities for permission to see [her]3475-my friend . [I]148-the governor [myself]148-the governor inquired if [she]3475-my friend had any relations living , and if [she]3475-my friend would like to see [them]3476-near relatives . [She]3475-my friend answered : "[148-the governor] None that [I]0-i care to see , or that care to see [me]0-i - except [the nearest relation of all]219-the nearest relation of all . " In those last words [the miserable creature]3481-the miserable creature alluded to [[her]3475-my friend only child]3482-her only child , [a little girl]3483-a little girl [an infant]3484-an infant , [I]219-the nearest relation of all should say , who had passed [her]3483-a little girl first year 's birthday by a few months . The farewell interview was to take place on [the mother]3485-the mother 's last evening on [earth]3486-earth ; and [the child]3474-the child was now brought into [[my]219-the nearest relation of all rooms]3488-my rooms , in charge of [[her]3475-my friend nurse]3489-her nurse . [I]219-the nearest relation of all had seldom seen [a brighter or prettier little girl]3490-a brighter or prettier little girl . [She]3474-the child was just able to walk alone , and to enjoy the first delight of moving from one place to another . Quite of [her]3474-the child own accord [she]3474-the child came to [me]219-the nearest relation of all , attracted [I]219-the nearest relation of all daresay by the glitter of [my]219-the nearest relation of all watch - chain . Helping [her]3474-the child to climb on [my]219-the nearest relation of all knee , [I]219-the nearest relation of all showed the wonders of the watch , and held it to [her]3474-the child ear . At that past time , death had taken [[my]219-the nearest relation of all good wife]3491-my good wife from [me]219-the nearest relation of all ; [[my]219-the nearest relation of all two boys]3492-my two boys were away at [Harrow School]1-harrow school ; [my]219-the nearest relation of all domestic life was the life of [a lonely man]3493-a lonely man . Whether [I]219-the nearest relation of all was reminded of the bygone days when [[my]219-the nearest relation of all sons]3494-my sons were infants on [my]219-the nearest relation of all knee , listening to the ticking of [my]219-the nearest relation of all watch - or whether the friendless position of the poor little creature , who had lost [one parent and was soon to lose the other by a violent death]3495-one parent and was soon to lose the other by a violent death , moved [me]219-the nearest relation of all in depths of pity not easily reached in [my]219-the nearest relation of all later experience - [I]219-the nearest relation of all am not able to say . This only [I]219-the nearest relation of all know : [my]219-the nearest relation of all heart ached for [the child]3474-the child while [she]3474-the child was laughing and listening ; and something fell from [me]219-the nearest relation of all on the watch which [I]219-the nearest relation of all do n't deny might have been a tear . A few of the toys , mostly broken now , which [[my]219-the nearest relation of all two children]3497-my two children used to play with are still in [my]219-the nearest relation of all possession ; kept , like [[my]219-the nearest relation of all poor wife]3498-my poor wife 's favorite jewels , for old remembrance ' sake . These [I]219-the nearest relation of all took from [their]3497-my two children repository when the attraction of [my]219-the nearest relation of all watch showed signs of failing . [The child]3474-the child pounced on [them]3497-my two children with [her]3474-the child chubby hands , and screamed with pleasure . And [the hangman]3500-the hangman was waiting for [[her]3474-the child mother]3501-her mother - and , more horrid still , [the mother]3485-the mother deserved it ! [My]219-the nearest relation of all duty required [me]219-the nearest relation of all to let [the Prisoner]158-the prisoner know that [[her]158-the prisoner little daughter]3504-her little daughter had arrived . Did that heart of iron melt at last ? It might have been so , or it might not ; the message sent back kept [her]3474-the child secret . All that it said to [me]219-the nearest relation of all was : "[219-the nearest relation of all] Let [the child]3474-the child wait till [I]0-i send for [her]3474-the child . " [The Minister]161-the minister had consented to help [us]3506-us . On [his]161-the minister arrival at [the prison]147-the prison , [I]0-i received [him]161-the minister privately in [[my]0-i study]3508-my study . [I]0-i had only to look at [his]161-the minister face - pitiably pale and agitated - to see that [he]161-the minister was [a sensitive man]3509-a sensitive man , not always able to control [his]161-the minister nerves on occasions which tried [his]161-the minister moral courage . A kind , [I]0-i might almost say [a noble face]3510-a noble face , and a voice unaffectedly persuasive , at once prepossessed [me]0-i in [his]161-the minister favor . The few words of welcome that [I]0-i spoke were intended to compose [him]161-the minister . They failed to produce the impression on which [I]0-i had counted . "[0-i] [My]0-i experience , " [he]161-the minister said , "[0-i] has included many melancholy duties , and has tried [my]0-i composure in terrible scenes ; but [I]0-i have never yet found [myself]0-i in the presence of [an unrepentant criminal]221-an unrepentant criminal , sentenced to death - and that criminal [a woman]222-a woman and [a mother]223-a mother . [I]0-i own , [sir]3443-sir , that [I]0-i am shaken by the prospect before [me]0-i . " [I]0-i suggested that [he]161-the minister should wait a while , in the hope that time and quiet might help [him]161-the minister . [He]161-the minister thanked [me]0-i , and refused . "[0-i] If [I]0-i have any knowledge of [myself]0-i , " [he]0-i said , "[0-i] terrors of anticipation lose their hold when [I]0-i am face to face with a serious call on [me]0-i . The longer [I]0-i remain [here]225-here , the less worthy [I]0-i shall appear of the trust that has been placed in [me]0-i - the trust which , please [God]38-god , [I]0-i mean to deserve . " [My]0-i own observation of human nature told [me]0-i that this was wisely said . [I]0-i led the way at once to [the cell]3511-the cell . CHAPTER IV . [THE MINISTER]161-the minister SAYS YES . [The Prisoner]158-the prisoner was seated on [her]158-the prisoner bed , quietly talking with [the woman appointed to watch [her]158-the prisoner]3514-the woman appointed to watch her . When [she]3514-the woman appointed to watch her rose to receive [us]3515-us , [I]0-i saw [the Minister]161-the minister start . The face that confronted [him]161-the minister would , in [my]0-i opinion , have taken [any man]3517-any man by surprise , if [he]161-the minister had first happened to see it within the walls of [a prison]3518-a prison . [Visitors to [the picture - galleries of [Italy]2-italy]3520-the picture - galleries of italy]3519-visitors to the picture - galleries of italy , growing weary of [Holy Families]3521-holy families in endless succession , observe that the idea of [the Madonna]3522-the madonna , among the rank and file of [Italian Painters]3523-italian painters , is limited to [one changeless and familiar type]3524-one changeless and familiar type . [I]0-i can hardly hope to be believed when [I]0-i say that the personal appearance of [the murderess]3525-the murderess recalled that type . [She]3525-the murderess presented the delicate light hair , the quiet eyes , the finely - shaped lower features and the correctly oval form of face , repeated in hundreds on hundreds of the conventional works of Art to which [I]0-i have ventured to allude . To those who doubt [me]0-i , [I]0-i can only declare that what [I]0-i have here written is undisguised and absolute truth . Let [me]0-i add that daily observation of [all classes of criminals]3526-all classes of criminals , extending over many years , has considerably diminished [my]0-i faith in physiognomy as a safe guide to the discovery of character . Nervous trepidation looks like guilt . Guilt , firmly sustained by insensibility , looks like innocence . When [she]291-a young woman there entered [the room]3541-the room , [I]291-a young woman there looked at [the woman]179-the woman attentively for the first time . [Her]291-a young woman there defects were , to [my]291-a young woman there mind , equally noticeable . " With that remarkable disavowal of the defense set up by [[her]392-she advocate]3715-her advocate , the confession ended . [[My]0-i colleague]3716-my colleague read the paper , and handed it back to [me]0-i without making any remark . [I]0-i asked if [he]3443-sir suspected [the Prisoner]158-the prisoner of feigning conversion to please [the Minister]161-the minister . "[0-i] [She]396-she shall not discover it , " [he]3443-sir answered , gravely , "[396-she] if [I]0-i do . " It would not be true to say that [the Doctor]162-the doctor 's obstinacy had shaken [my]0-i belief in the good result of [the Minister]161-the minister 's interference . [I]0-i may , however , acknowledge that [I]0-i felt some misgivings , which were not dispelled when [I]0-i found [myself]0-i in the presence of [the Prisoner]158-the prisoner . [I]0-i had expected to see [her]396-she employed in reading the Bible . The good book was closed and was not even placed within [her]396-she reach . ' " CHAPTER VIII . [THE MINISTER]161-the minister SAYS GOOD - BY . The Capital Punishment of [the Prisoner]158-the prisoner is in no respect connected with [my]439-the people purpose in writing the present narrative . Try as [I]3466-your friend might , [I]3466-your friend failed to feel [the Minister]161-the minister 's comforting conviction as to which of the two would win . CHAPTER IX . [THE GOVERNOR]148-the governor RECEIVES A VISIT . A few days after [the good man]3789-the good man had left [us]3785-we , [I]3466-your friend met with a serious accident , caused by a false step on the stone stairs of [the prison]147-the prison . The long illness which followed this misfortune , and [my]3466-your friend removal afterward in the interests of [my]3466-your friend recovery to a milder climate than the climate of [England]4-england , obliged [me]3466-your friend to confide the duties of [governor of [the prison]147-the prison]3791-governor of the prison to [a representative]3793-a representative . [I]3466-your friend was absent from [my]3466-your friend post for rather more than a year . During this interval no news reached [me]3466-your friend from [[my]3466-your friend reverend friend]3794-my reverend friend . Having returned to the duties of [[my]3466-your friend office]3574-my office , [I]3466-your friend thought of writing to [the Minister]161-the minister . While the proposed letter was still in contemplation , [I]3466-your friend was informed that [a lady]210-a lady wished to see [me]3466-your friend . [She]210-a lady sent in [her]210-a lady card . [[My]3466-your friend visitor]3798-my visitor proved to be [[the Minister]161-the minister 's wife]3800-the minister 's wife . [I]3466-your friend observed [her]210-a lady with no ordinary attention when [she]210-a lady entered [the room]3541-the room . [Her]210-a lady dress was simple ; [her]210-a lady scanty light hair , so far as [I]3466-your friend could see it under [her]210-a lady bonnet , was dressed with taste . The paleness of [her]210-a lady lips , and the faded color in [her]210-a lady face , suggested that [she]210-a lady was certainly not in good health . Two peculiarities struck [me]3466-your friend in [her]210-a lady personal appearance . [I]3466-your friend never remembered having seen [any other person with such a singularly narrow and slanting forehead]3802-any other person with such a singularly narrow and slanting forehead as [this lady]3803-this lady presented ; and [I]3466-your friend was impressed , not at all agreeably , by the flashing shifting expression in [her]210-a lady eyes . On the other hand , let [me]3466-your friend own that [I]3466-your friend was powerfully attracted and interested by the beauty of [her]210-a lady voice . Its fine variety of compass , and its musical resonance of tone , fell with such enchantment on the ear , that [I]3466-your friend should have liked to put a book of poetry into [her]210-a lady hand , and to have heard [her]210-a lady read it in summer - time , accompanied by the music of a rocky stream . The object of [her]210-a lady visit - so far as [she]210-a lady explained it at the outset - appeared to be to offer [her]210-a lady congratulations on [my]3466-your friend recovery , and to tell [me]3466-your friend that [[her]210-a lady husband]168-her husband had assumed the charge of a church in [a large town not far from [[her]210-a lady birthplace]3806-her birthplace]3805-a large town not far from her birthplace . Even those commonplace words were made interesting by [her]210-a lady delicious voice . But however sensitive to sweet sounds [a man]3697-a man may be , there are limits to [his]3697-a man capacity for deceiving [himself]3697-a man - especially when [he]3697-a man happens to be enlightened by experience of humanity within the walls of [a prison]3518-a prison . [I]3466-your friend had , it may be remembered , already doubted [the lady]3781-the lady 's good temper , judging from [[her]210-a lady husband]168-her husband 's over - wrought description of [her]210-a lady virtues . [Her]210-a lady eyes looked at [me]3466-your friend furtively ; and [her]210-a lady manner , gracefully self - possessed as it was , suggested that [she]210-a lady had something of a delicate , or disagreeable , nature to say to [me]3466-your friend , and that [she]210-a lady was at a loss how to approach the subject so as to produce the right impression on [my]3466-your friend mind at the outset . There was a momentary silence between [us]460-our . For the sake of saying something , [I]3466-your friend asked how [she]210-a lady and [the Minister]161-the minister liked [[their]460-our new place of residence]3812-their new place of residence . "[3466-your friend] [[Our]460-our new place of residence]461-our new place of residence , " [she]210-a lady answered , "[3466-your friend] has been made interesting by a very unexpected event - an event how shall [I]0-i describe it ? which has increased [our]460-our happiness and enlarged [[our]460-our family circle]462-our family circle . " There [she]210-a lady stopped : expecting [me]0-i , as [I]0-i fancied , to guess what [she]210-a lady meant . [A woman]222-a woman , and [that woman]271-that woman [a mother]223-a mother , might have fulfilled [her]210-a lady anticipations . MISS CHANCE REAPPEARS . A week had passed , since [[the Minister]161-the minister 's wife]3800-the minister 's wife had left [me]0-i , when [I]0-i received a letter from [the Minister]161-the minister [himself]161-the minister . After surprising [me]0-i , as [he]161-the minister innocently supposed , by announcing the birth of [[his]161-the minister child]495-his child , [he]161-the minister mentioned some circumstances connected with that event , which [I]0-i now heard for the first time . " Within an easy journey of the populous scene of [my]161-the minister present labors , "[161-the minister] [he]161-the minister wrote , " there is [a secluded country village called [Low Lanes]5-low lanes]3867-a secluded country village called low lanes . [The rector of [the place]3869-the place]3868-the rector of the place is [[my]161-the minister wife 's brother]3870-my wife 's brother . "[161-the minister] In this semi - hysterical style of writing , [the poor man]496-the poor man unconsciously told [me]0-i how cunningly and how cruelly [[his]496-the poor man wife]174-his wife was deceiving [him]496-the poor man . " [I]161-the minister am not aware , "[161-the minister] [he]161-the minister wrote , " whether [I]161-the minister have , or have not , committed an offense against the Law . "[161-the minister] Six weeks passed , and [I]0-i heard from [[my]0-i reverend friend]3794-my reverend friend once more . [His]161-the minister second letter presented a marked contrast to the first . It was written in sorrow and anxiety , to inform [me]0-i of an alarming change for the worse in [[his]161-the minister wife]174-his wife 's health . [I]0-i showed the letter to [[my]0-i medical colleague]520-my medical colleague . On the next occasion when [I]0-i heard from [the Minister]161-the minister , [the Doctor]162-the doctor 's grim reply proved to be a prophecy fulfilled . When [we]523-we address expressions of condolence to [bereaved friends]524-bereaved friends , the principles of popular hypocrisy sanction indiscriminate lying as a duty which [we]523-we owe to [the dead]525-the dead - no matter what [their]525-the dead lives may have been - because [they]525-the dead are dead . Within [my]0-i own little sphere , [I]0-i have always been silent , when [I]0-i could not offer to [afflicted persons]526-afflicted persons expressions of sympathy which [I]0-i honestly felt . To have condoled with [the Minister]161-the minister on the loss that [he]161-the minister had sustained by the death of [a woman]222-a woman , self - betrayed to [me]0-i as shamelessly deceitful , and pitilessly determined to reach [her]222-a woman own cruel ends , would have been to degrade [myself]0-i by telling a deliberate lie . [I]0-i expressed in [my]0-i answer all that [an honest man]165-an honest man naturally feels , when [he]165-an honest man is writing to [a friend in distress]530-a friend in distress ; carefully abstaining from any allusion to the memory of [[his]165-an honest man wife]174-his wife , or to the place which [her]222-a woman death had left vacant in [[his]165-an honest man household]532-his household . [He]165-an honest man wrote to [me]0-i no more , until years had passed , and time had exerted its influence in producing a more indulgent frame of mind . [The correspondent whom [I]0-i had now lost]533-the correspondent whom i had now lost was succeeded by [a gentleman entirely unknown to [me]0-i]534-a gentleman entirely unknown to me . [The father]548-the father was naturally anxious that [the son]549-the son should never become acquainted with the disgrace that had befallen [the family]550-the family . "[548-the father] If [you]551-you feel some surprise at finding that [my]0-i good intentions toward [this ill - fated niece of [mine]0-i]552-this ill - fated niece of mine do not go to the length of receiving [her]552-this ill - fated niece of mine as [a member of [[my]0-i own family]554-my own family]553-a member of my own family , [I]0-i beg to submit some considerations which may perhaps weigh with [you]551-you as they have weighed with [me]0-i . " In the first place , there is at least a possibility - however carefully [I]0-i might try to conceal it - that [the child]3474-the child 's parentage would sooner or later be discovered . In the second place and assuming that the parentage had been successfully concealed , if [this girl]3898-this girl and [[my]0-i boy]3899-my boy grew up together , there is another possibility to be reckoned with : [they]3900-they might become attached to [each other]3725-each other . [[My]0-i correspondent]555-my correspondent had strongly impressed [me]0-i in [his]555-my correspondent favor ; [I]0-i could not doubt that [he]555-my correspondent was [an honorable man]412-an honorable man . The absolutely safe course to take was to admit [no one]455-no one , [friend]560-friend or [stranger]561-stranger , to [our]562-our confidence . [I]0-i replied , expressing sincere admiration of [Mr. Dunboyne]47-philip 's motives , and merely informing [him]47-philip that [the child]3474-the child was already provided for . After that , [I]0-i heard no more of [the Irish gentleman]564-the irish gentleman . It is perhaps hardly necessary to add that [I]0-i kept [the Minister]161-the minister in ignorance of [my]0-i correspondence with [Mr. Dunboyne]47-philip . [I]0-i was too well acquainted with [[my]0-i friend]3475-my friend 's sensitive and self - tormenting nature to let [him]47-philip know that [a relative of the murderess]567-a relative of the murderess was living , and was aware that [she]567-a relative of the murderess had left [a child]256-a child . A last event remains to be related , before [I]0-i close these pages . During the year of which [I]0-i am now writing , [[our]562-our Chaplain]188-our chaplain added one more to the many examples that [I]0-i have seen of [his]47-philip generous readiness to serve [[his]47-philip friends]570-his friends . [He]47-philip had arranged to devote [his]47-philip annual leave of absence to a tour among [the English Lakes]571-the english lakes , when [he]47-philip received a letter from [a clergyman resident in [London]3-london , whom [he]47-philip had known from the time when [they]573-they had been [school - fellows]574-school - fellows]572-a clergyman resident in london , whom he had known from the time when they had been school - fellows . [This old friend]575-this old friend wrote under circumstances of the severest domestic distress , which made it absolutely necessary that [he]47-philip should leave [London]3-london for a while . [He]47-philip smiled significantly when [he]47-philip answered [me]0-i . " [I]47-philip have a card to deliver from [an acquaintance whom [you]0-i have not mentioned]3906-an acquaintance whom you have not mentioned , "[47-philip] [he]47-philip said ; " and [I]47-philip rather think it will astonish [you]0-i . " Perhaps [you]0-i may remember [her]584-the dangerous creature who had first presented herself to me , in charge of the prisoner 's child maiden name ? [I]0-i asked a stupid question : " How did it happen ? "[0-i] " In the ordinary course of such things , "[3475-my friend] [[my]0-i friend]3475-my friend said . " [They]3911-they were married by license , in [[their]3911-they parish church]3912-their parish church . [THE GIRLS]50-the girls AND [THE JOURNALS]51-the journals . CHAPTER XI . [HELENA]52-helena 'S DIARY . [We]593-we both said good - night , and went up to [[our]593-we room]594-our room with a new object in view . By [[our]593-we father]595-our father 's advice [we]593-we had resolved on keeping diaries , for the first time in [our]593-we lives , and had pledged [ourselves]593-we to begin before [we]593-we went to bed . Slowly and silently and lazily , [[my]0-i sister]596-my sister sauntered to [her]596-my sister end of [the room]3541-the room and seated [herself]596-my sister at [her]596-my sister writing - table . On the desk lay a nicely bound book , full of blank pages . The word " Journal "[596-my sister] was printed on it in gold letters , and there was fitted to the covers a bright brass lock and key . A second journal , exactly similar in every respect to the first , was placed on the writing - table at [my]0-i end of [the room]3541-the room . [I]0-i opened [my]0-i book . The sight of the blank leaves irritated [me]0-i ; they were so smooth , so spotless , so entirely ready to do their duty . [I]0-i took too deep a dip of ink , and began the first entry in [my]0-i diary by making a blot . This was discouraging . [I]0-i got up , and looked out of window . " [Helena]52-helena ! "[0-i] [[My]0-i sister]596-my sister 's voice could hardly have addressed [me]0-i in a more weary tone , if [her]596-my sister pen had been at work all night , relating domestic events . " Well ! "[0-i] [I]0-i said . " What is it ? "[0-i] " Have [you]0-i done already ? "[596-my sister] [she]596-my sister asked . [I]0-i showed [her]596-my sister the blot . [[My]0-i sister]596-my sister [Eunice]53-eunice the strangest as well as [the dearest of [girls]602-girls]601-the dearest of girls always blurts out what [she]596-my sister has in [her]596-my sister mind at the time . [She]596-my sister fixed [her]596-my sister eyes gravely on [my]0-i spoiled page , and said : " That comforts [me]596-my sister . "[596-my sister] [I]0-i crossed [the room]3541-the room , and looked at [her]596-my sister book . [She]596-my sister had not even summoned energy enough to make a blot . " What will [papa]3923-he think of [us]3924-us , "[596-my sister] [she]596-my sister said , " if [we]3924-us do n't begin to - night ? "[596-my sister] " Why not begin , "[0-i] [I]0-i suggested , " by writing down what [he]3923-he said , when [he]3923-he gave [us]3924-us [our]3924-us journals ? Those wise words of advice will be in their proper place on the first page of the new books . "[596-my sister] Not at all [a demonstrative girl]604-a demonstrative girl naturally ; not ready with [her]596-my sister tears , not liberal with [her]596-my sister caresses , not fluent in [her]596-my sister talk , [Eunice]53-eunice was affected by [my]0-i proposal in a manner wonderful to see . [She]53-eunice suddenly developed into [an excitable person]605-an excitable person - [I]0-i declare [she]53-eunice kissed [me]0-i . " Oh , "[53-eunice] [she]53-eunice burst out , " how clever [you]0-i are ! The very thing to write about ; [I]53-eunice 'll do it directly . "[53-eunice] [She]53-eunice really did it directly ; without once stopping to consider , without once waiting to ask [my]0-i advice . Line after line , [I]0-i heard [her]53-eunice noisy pen hurrying to the bottom of a first page , and getting three - parts of the way toward the end of a second page , before [she]53-eunice closed [her]53-eunice diary . [I]0-i reminded [her]53-eunice that [she]53-eunice had not turned the key , in the lock which was intended to keep [her]53-eunice writing private . " It 's not worth while , "[53-eunice] [she]53-eunice answered . " [Anybody who cares to do it]3925-anybody who cares to do it may read what [I]53-eunice write . Good - night . "[53-eunice] The singular change which [I]0-i had noticed in [her]53-eunice began to disappear , when [she]53-eunice set about [her]53-eunice preparations for bed . [I]0-i noticed the old easy indolent movements again , and that regular and deliberate method of brushing [her]53-eunice hair , which [I]0-i can never contemplate without feeling a stupefying influence that has helped [me]0-i to many a delicious night 's sleep . [She]53-eunice said [her]53-eunice prayers in [[her]53-eunice favorite corner of [the room]3541-the room]606-her favorite corner of the room , and laid [her]53-eunice head on the pillow with the luxurious little sigh which announces that [she]53-eunice is falling asleep . This reappearance of [her]53-eunice usual habits was really a relief to [me]0-i . [Eunice]53-eunice in a state of excitement is [Eunice]53-eunice exhibiting an unnatural spectacle . The next thing [I]0-i did was to take the liberty which [she]53-eunice had already sanctioned - [I]0-i mean the liberty of reading what [she]53-eunice had written . Here it is , copied exactly : " [I]53-eunice am not half so fond of [anybody]3926-anybody as [I]53-eunice am of [papa]3927-papa . [He]3927-papa is always kind , [he]3927-papa is always right . [I]53-eunice love [him]3927-papa , [I]53-eunice love [him]3927-papa , [I]53-eunice love [him]3927-papa . "[53-eunice] But this is not how [I]0-i meant to begin . [I]0-i must tell how [he]608-he talked to [us]609-us ; [I]0-i wish [he]608-he was here to tell it [himself]608-he . " [He]608-he said to [me]608-he : ' [You]608-he are getting lazier than ever , [Eunice]53-eunice . ' [He]608-he said to [Helena]52-helena : ' [You]52-helena are feeling the influence of [Eunice]53-eunice 's example . ' [He]608-he said to [both of [us]610-us]3928-both of us : ' [You]608-he are too ready , [[my]608-he dear children]3929-my dear children , to sit with [your]608-he hands on [your]608-he laps , looking at nothing and thinking of nothing ; [I]608-he want to try a new way of employing [your]608-he leisure time . ' "[608-he] [He]608-he opened a parcel on the table . [He]608-he made each of [us]610-us a present of a beautiful book , called ' Journal . ' [He]608-he said : ' When [you]610-us have nothing to do , [[my]0-i dears]611-my dears , in the evening , employ [yourselves]610-us in keeping a diary of the events of the day . It will be a useful record in many ways , and a good moral discipline for [young girls]612-young girls . ' [Helena]52-helena said : ' Oh , thank [you]608-he ! ' [I]0-i said the same , but not so cheerfully . " The truth is , [I]0-i feel out of spirits now if [I]0-i think of [papa]3927-papa ; [I]0-i am not easy in [my]0-i mind about [him]3927-papa . When [he]3927-papa is very much interested , there is a quivering in [his]3927-papa face which [I]0-i do n't remember in past times . [He]3927-papa seems to have got older and thinner , all on a sudden . [He]3927-papa shouts which [he]3927-papa never used to do when [he]3927-papa threatens [sinners]3931-sinners at sermon - time . Being in dreadful earnest about [our]3932-our souls , [he]3927-papa is of course obliged to speak of the devil ; but [he]3927-papa never used to hit the harmless pulpit cushion with [his]3927-papa fist as [he]3927-papa does now . [Nobody]305-nobody seems to have seen these things but [me]0-i ; and now [I]0-i have noticed [them]3934-them what ought [I]0-i to do ? [I]0-i do n't know ; [I]0-i am certain of nothing , except what [I]0-i have put in at the top of page one : [I]0-i love [him]3927-papa , [I]0-i love [him]3927-papa , [I]0-i love [him]3927-papa . "[0-i] ....... There this very curious entry ended . It was easy enough to discover the influence which had made [[my]0-i slow - minded sister]613-my slow - minded sister so ready with [her]613-my slow - minded sister memory and [her]613-my slow - minded sister pen - so ready , in short , to do anything and everything , provided [her]613-my slow - minded sister heart was in it , and [[her]613-my slow - minded sister father]614-her father was in it . But [Eunice]53-eunice is wrong , let [me]0-i tell [her]53-eunice , in what [she]53-eunice says of [myself]0-i . [I]0-i , too , have seen the sad change in [[my]0-i father]615-my father ; but [I]0-i happen to know that [he]615-my father dislikes having it spoken of at [home]258-home , and [I]0-i have kept [my]0-i painful discoveries to [myself]0-i . Unhappily , the best medical advice is beyond [our]617-our reach . [The one really competent doctor in [this place]443-this place]618-the one really competent doctor in this place is known to be [an infidel]620-an infidel . But for that shocking obstacle [I]0-i might have persuaded [[my]0-i father]615-my father to see [him]618-the one really competent doctor in this place . As for [the other two doctors whom [he]615-my father has consulted]622-the other two doctors whom he has consulted , at different times , [one]431-one talked about suppressed gout , and [the other]432-the other told [him]615-my father to take a year 's holiday and enjoy [himself]615-my father on [the Continent]625-the continent . The clock has just struck twelve . [I]0-i have been writing and copying till [my]0-i eyes are heavy , and [I]0-i want to follow [Eunice]53-eunice 's example and sleep as soundly as [she]53-eunice does . [We]617-our have made a strange beginning of this journalizing experiment . [I]0-i wonder how long it will go on , and what will come of it . SECOND DAY . [I]0-i begin to be afraid that [I]0-i am as stupid - no ; that is not a nice word to use - let [me]0-i say as simple as dear [Eunice]53-eunice . A diary means a record of the events of the day ; and not one of the events of yesterday appears in [[my]0-i sister]596-my sister 's journal or in [mine]0-i . Well , it is easy to set that mistake right . [Our]617-our lives are so dull but [I]0-i would not say so in [[my]0-i father]615-my father 's hearing for [the world]364-the world that the record of one day will be much the same as the record of another . After family prayers and breakfast [I]0-i suffer [my]0-i customary persecution at the hands of [the cook]629-the cook . That is to say , [I]0-i am obliged , being [the housekeeper]630-the housekeeper , to order what [we]617-our have to eat . Oh , how [I]0-i hate inventing dinners ! and how [I]0-i admire the enviable slowness of mind and laziness of body which have saved [Eunice]53-eunice from undertaking the worries of housekeeping in [her]53-eunice turn ! [She]53-eunice can go and work in [[her]53-eunice garden]631-her garden , while [I]0-i am racking [my]0-i invention to discover variety in dishes without overstepping the limits of economy . [I]0-i suppose [I]0-i may confess it privately to [myself]0-i - how sorry [I]0-i am not to have been born [a man]3697-a man ! [My]0-i next employment leads [me]0-i to [[[my]0-i father]615-my father 's study]634-my father 's study , to write under [his]615-my father dictation . [I]0-i do n't complain of this ; it flatters [my]0-i pride to feel that [I]0-i am helping [so great a man]635-so great a man . At the same time , [I]0-i do notice that here again [Eunice]53-eunice 's little defects have relieved [her]53-eunice of another responsibility . [She]53-eunice can neither keep dictated words in [her]53-eunice memory , nor has [she]53-eunice ever been able to learn how to put in [her]53-eunice stops . After the dictation , [I]0-i have an hour 's time left for practicing music . [[My]0-i sister]596-my sister comes in from [the garden]637-the garden , with [her]596-my sister pencil and paint - box , and practices drawing . Then [we]638-we go out for a walk - a delightful walk , if [[my]0-i father]615-my father goes too . [He]615-my father has something always new to tell [us]638-we , suggested by what [we]638-we pass on the way . Then , dinner - time comes - not always a pleasant part of the day to [me]0-i . Sometimes [I]0-i hear paternal complaints always gentle complaints of [[my]0-i housekeeping]640-my housekeeping ; sometimes [[my]0-i sister]596-my sister [I]0-i wo n't say [the greedy sister]642-the greedy sister tells [me]0-i [I]0-i have not given [her]596-my sister enough to eat . [Poor father]643-poor father ! [Dear Eunice]53-eunice ! Dinner having reached its end , [we]638-we stroll in [the garden]637-the garden when the weather is fine . When it rains , [we]638-we make flannel petticoats for [poor old women]645-poor old women . What a horrid thing old age is to look at ! To be ugly , to be helpless , to be miserably unfit for all the pleasures of life - [I]0-i hope [I]0-i shall not live to be [an old woman]646-an old woman . What would [[my]0-i father]615-my father say if [he]615-my father saw this ? For [his]615-my father sake , to say nothing of [my]0-i own feelings , [I]0-i shall do well if [I]0-i make it a custom to use the lock of [my]0-i journal . [Our]638-we next occupation is to join the Scripture class for [girls]602-girls , and to help [the teacher]649-the teacher . This is a good discipline for [Eunice]53-eunice 's temper , and - oh , [I]0-i do n't deny it ! - for [my]0-i temper , too . [I]0-i may long to box the ears of [the whole class]650-the whole class , but it is [my]0-i duty to keep a smiling face and to be [a model of patience]651-a model of patience . From the Scripture class [we]638-we sometimes go to [[my]0-i father]615-my father 's lecture . At other times , [we]638-we may amuse [ourselves]638-we as well as [we]638-we can till the tea is ready . After tea , [we]638-we read books which instruct [us]638-we , poetry and novels being forbidden . When [we]638-we are tired of the books [we]638-we talk . When supper is over , [we]638-we have prayers again , and [we]638-we go to bed . There is [our]638-we day . Oh , dear [me]0-i ! there is [our]638-we day . ....... And how has [Eunice]53-eunice succeeded in [her]53-eunice second attempt at keeping a diary ? Here is what [she]53-eunice has written . It has one merit that [nobody]305-nobody can deny - it is soon read : " [I]53-eunice hope [papa]3927-papa will excuse [me]53-eunice ; [I]53-eunice have nothing to write about to - day . "[53-eunice] Over and over again [I]0-i have tried to point out to [[my]0-i sister]596-my sister the absurdity of calling [[her]596-my sister father]614-her father by the infantile nickname of [papa]3927-papa . [I]0-i have reminded [her]596-my sister that [she]596-my sister is in years , at least no longer [a child]256-a child . " Why do n't [you]596-my sister call [him]3927-papa [father]3936-father , as [I]0-i do ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked only the other day . [She]596-my sister made an absurd reply : " [I]596-my sister used to call [him]3927-papa [papa]3927-papa when [I]596-my sister was [a little girl]3483-a little girl . "[596-my sister] " That , "[0-i] [I]0-i reminded [her]596-my sister , " does n't justify [you]596-my sister in calling [him]3927-papa [papa]3927-papa now . "[0-i] And [she]596-my sister actually answered : " Yes it does . "[596-my sister] What a strange state of mind ! And what [a charming girl]658-a charming girl , in spite of [her]596-my sister mind ! THIRD DAY . The morning post has brought with it a promise of some little variety in [our]659-our lives - or , to speak more correctly , in the life of [[my]0-i sister]596-my sister . [[Our]659-our new and nice friends]661-our new and nice friends , [the Staveleys]54-the staveleys , have written to invite [Eunice]53-eunice to pay [them]661-our new and nice friends a visit at [[their]661-our new and nice friends house in [London]3-london]662-their house in london . [I]0-i do n't complain at being left at [home]258-home . It would be unfilial , indeed , if [we]659-our both of [us]659-our forsook [[our]659-our father]595-our father ; and last year it was [my]0-i turn to receive the first invitation , and to enjoy the change of scene . [The Staveleys]54-the staveleys are [excellent people]665-excellent people - [strictly pious members of [the Methodist Connection]667-the methodist connection]666-strictly pious members of the methodist connection - and exceedingly kind to [[my]0-i sister]596-my sister and [me]0-i . But it was just as well for [my]0-i moral welfare that [I]0-i ended [my]0-i visit to [[our]659-our friends]669-our friends when [I]0-i did . With [my]0-i fondness for music , [I]0-i felt the temptation of the Evil One trying [me]0-i , when [I]0-i saw placards in [the street]670-the street announcing that [the Italian Opera]671-the italian opera was open . [I]0-i had no wish to be a witness of the shameful and sinful dancing which goes on [I]0-i am told at the opera ; but [I]0-i did feel [my]0-i principles shaken when [I]0-i thought of [the wonderful singers and the entrancing music]672-the wonderful singers and the entrancing music . And this , when [I]0-i knew what an atmosphere of wickedness [people]673-people breathe who enter [a theater]674-a theater ! [I]0-i reflect with horror on what might have happened if [I]0-i had remained a little longer in [London]3-london . Helping [Eunice]53-eunice to pack up , [I]0-i put [her]53-eunice journal into the box . " [You]53-eunice will find something to write about now , "[0-i] [I]0-i told [her]53-eunice . " While [I]0-i record everything that happens at [home]258-home , [you]53-eunice will keep [your]53-eunice diary of all that [you]53-eunice do in [London]3-london , and when [you]53-eunice come back [we]3941-we will show [each other]3725-each other what [we]3941-we have written . "[0-i] [[My]0-i sister]596-my sister is [a dear creature]676-a dear creature . " [I]596-my sister do n't feel sure of being able to do it , "[596-my sister] [she]596-my sister answered ; " but [I]596-my sister promise to try . "[596-my sister] [Good Eunice]53-eunice ! CHAPTER XII . EUNICE 'S DIARY . The air of [London]3-london feels very heavy . There is a nasty smell of smoke in [London]3-london . There are too many people in [London]3-london . [They]677-they seem to be mostly [people in a hurry]678-people in a hurry . [The head of [a country girl]680-a country girl]679-the head of a country girl , when [she]680-a country girl goes into [the streets]681-the streets , turns giddy - [I]0-i suppose through not being used to the noise . [I]0-i do hope that it is [London]3-london that has put [me]0-i out of temper . Otherwise , it must be [I]0-i [myself]0-i who am ill - tempered . All [London]3-london is going just now to the exhibition of pictures . [We]738-we are going with all [London]3-london . ....... [I]0-i do n't know what is the matter with [me]0-i tonight . [I]0-i have positively been to bed , without going to sleep ! After tossing and twisting and trying all sorts of positions , [I]0-i am so angry with [myself]0-i that [I]0-i have got up again . [I]0-i have said that to [myself]0-i fifty times over . And here it is , saying itself for the fifty - first time in [my]0-i Journal . [I]0-i must indeed be [a simpleton]3964-a simpleton , as [Helena]52-helena says . [I]0-i had better go to bed again . CHAPTER XIII . [EUNICE]53-eunice 'S DIARY . Not long before [I]0-i left [home]258-home , [I]0-i heard [one of [[our]762-our two servants]763-our two servants]761-one of our two servants telling [the other]432-the other about [a person who had been " bewitched]3973-a person who had been " bewitched . "[761-one of our two servants] Are [you]765-you bewitched when [you]765-you do n't understand [your]765-you own self ? That has been [my]0-i curious case , since [I]0-i returned from the picture show . This morning [I]0-i took [my]0-i drawing materials out of [my]0-i box , and tried to make a portrait of [young Mr. Dunboyne]57-young mr. dunboyne from recollection . [I]0-i succeeded pretty well with [his]57-young mr. dunboyne frock - coat and cane ; but , try as [I]0-i might , [his]57-young mr. dunboyne face was beyond [me]0-i . [I]0-i have never drawn anything so badly since [I]0-i was [a little girl]3483-a little girl ; [I]0-i almost felt ready to cry . What [a fool]767-a fool [I]0-i am ! This morning [I]0-i received a letter from [papa]3927-papa - it was in reply to a letter that [I]0-i had written to [him]3927-papa - so kind , so beautifully expressed , so like [himself]3927-papa , that [I]0-i felt inclined to send [him]3927-papa a confession of the strange state of feeling that has come over [me]0-i , and to ask [him]3927-papa to comfort and advise [me]0-i . On second thoughts , [I]0-i was afraid to do it . Afraid of [papa]3927-papa ! [I]0-i am further away from understanding [myself]0-i than ever . [Mr. Dunboyne]57-young mr. dunboyne paid [us]770-us a visit in the afternoon . Fortunately , before [we]770-us went out . [I]0-i thought [I]0-i would have a good look at [him]3927-papa ; so as to know [his]3927-papa face better than [I]0-i had known it yet . Another disappointment was in store for [me]0-i . Without intending it , [I]0-i am sure , [he]3927-papa did what [no other young man]771-no other young man has ever done - [he]3927-papa made [me]0-i feel confused . Instead of looking at [him]3927-papa , [I]0-i sat with [my]0-i head down , and listened to [his]3927-papa talk . [His]3927-papa voice - this is high praise - reminded [me]0-i of [papa]3927-papa 's voice . It seemed to persuade [me]0-i as [papa]3927-papa persuades [[his]3927-papa congregation]774-his congregation . [I]0-i felt quite at ease again . When [he]3927-papa went away , [we]775-we shook hands . [He]3927-papa gave [my]0-i hand a little squeeze . [I]0-i gave [him]3927-papa back the squeeze - without knowing why . When [he]3927-papa was gone , [I]0-i wished [I]0-i had not done it - without knowing why , either . [I]0-i heard [his]3927-papa Christian name for the first time to - day . [Mrs. Staveley]59-mrs. staveley said to [me]0-i : " [We]775-we are going to have a dinner - party . Shall [I]59-mrs. staveley ask [Philip Dunboyne]47-philip ? "[59-mrs. staveley] [I]0-i said to [Mrs. Staveley]59-mrs. staveley : " Oh , do ! "[0-i] [She]59-mrs. staveley is [an old woman]646-an old woman ; [her]59-mrs. staveley eyes are dim . At times , [she]59-mrs. staveley can look mischievous . [She]59-mrs. staveley looked at [me]0-i mischievously now . [I]0-i wished [I]0-i had not been so eager to have [Mr. Dunboyne]47-philip asked to dinner . A fear has come to [me]0-i that [I]0-i may have degraded [myself]0-i . [My]0-i spirits are depressed . This , as [papa]3927-papa tells [us]778-us in [his]3927-papa sermons , is [a miserable world]779-a miserable world . [I]0-i am sorry [I]0-i accepted [the Staveleys]54-the staveleys ' invitation . [I]0-i am sorry [I]0-i went to see the pictures . When [that young man]780-that young man comes to dinner , [I]0-i shall say [I]0-i have got a headache , and shall stop [upstairs]3864-upstairs by [myself]0-i . [I]0-i do n't think [I]0-i like [his]780-that young man Christian name . [I]0-i hate [London]3-london . [I]0-i hate [everybody]3957-everybody . What [I]0-i wrote up above , yesterday , is nonsense . [I]0-i think [his]780-that young man Christian name is perfect . [I]0-i like [London]3-london . [I]0-i love [everybody]3957-everybody . [He]780-that young man came to dinner to - day . [I]0-i sat next to [him]780-that young man . How beautiful a dress - coat is , and a white cravat ! [We]784-we talked . [He]780-that young man wanted to know what [my]0-i Christian name was . [I]0-i was so pleased when [I]0-i found [he]780-that young man was one of [the few people who like it]785-the few people who like it . [His]780-that young man hair curls naturally . In color , it is something between [my]0-i hair and [Helena]52-helena 's . [He]780-that young man wears [his]780-that young man beard . How manly ! It curls naturally , like [his]780-that young man hair ; it smells deliciously of some perfume which is new to [me]0-i . [He]780-that young man has white hands ; [his]780-that young man nails look as if [he]780-that young man polished them ; [I]0-i should like to polish [my]0-i nails if [I]0-i knew how . Whatever [I]0-i said , [he]780-that young man agreed with [me]0-i ; [I]0-i felt satisfied with [my]0-i own conversation , for the first time in [my]0-i life . [Helena]52-helena wo n't find [me]0-i [a simpleton]3964-a simpleton when [I]0-i go [home]258-home . What exquisite things dinner - parties are ! [[My]0-i sister]596-my sister told [me]0-i when [we]789-we said good - by to be particular in writing down [my]0-i true opinion of [the Staveleys]54-the staveleys . [Helena]52-helena wishes to compare what [she]52-helena thinks of [them]54-the staveleys with what [I]0-i think of [them]54-the staveleys . [My]0-i opinion of [Mr. Staveley]60-mr. staveley is - [I]0-i do n't like [him]60-mr. staveley . [My]0-i opinion of [Miss Staveley]61-miss staveley is - [I]0-i ca n't endure [her]61-miss staveley . As for [Master Staveley]60-mr. staveley , [[my]0-i clever sister]790-my clever sister will understand that [he]60-mr. staveley is beneath notice . But , oh , what [a wonderful woman]791-a wonderful woman [Mrs. Staveley]59-mrs. staveley is ! [We]792-we went out together , after luncheon today , for a walk in [Kensington Gardens]10-kensington gardens . Never have [I]0-i heard any conversation to compare with [Mrs. Staveley]59-mrs. staveley 's . [Helena]52-helena shall enjoy it here , at second hand . [I]0-i am quite changed in two things . First : [I]0-i think more of [myself]0-i than [I]0-i ever did before . Second : writing is no longer a difficulty to [me]0-i . [I]0-i could fill a hundred journals , without once stopping to think . [Mrs. Staveley]59-mrs. staveley began nicely ; " [I]59-mrs. staveley suppose , [Eunice]53-eunice , [you]53-eunice have often been told that [you]53-eunice have a good figure , and that [you]53-eunice walk well ? "[59-mrs. staveley] [I]0-i said : " [Helena]52-helena thinks [my]0-i figure is better than [my]0-i face . But do [I]0-i really walk well ? [Nobody]305-nobody ever told [me]0-i that . "[0-i] [She]59-mrs. staveley answered : " [Philip Dunboyne]47-philip thinks so . ' "[59-mrs. staveley] [I]0-i stood stockstill . [I]0-i said nothing . [[My]0-i sister]596-my sister is [a musician]842-a musician - [I]0-i am nothing . That sounds bitter ; but [I]0-i do n't mean it so . All [I]0-i mean is , that [I]0-i like simple little songs , which [I]0-i can sing to [myself]0-i by remembering the tune . There , [my]0-i musical enjoyment ends . When voices and instruments burst out together by hundreds , [I]0-i feel bewildered . [I]0-i also get attacked by fidgets . This last misfortune is sure to overtake [me]0-i when choruses are being performed . The effect of it on [me]0-i may be told in two words : [I]0-i screamed . [Mrs. Staveley]59-mrs. staveley was naturally alarmed . " Bad news ? "[59-mrs. staveley] [she]59-mrs. staveley asked . This was [Helena]52-helena 's news from [home]258-home : " [I]52-helena must prepare [you]0-i for a surprise , before [your]0-i return . [You]0-i will find [a strange lady established at [home]258-home]4024-a strange lady established at home . "[59-mrs. staveley] But [Mrs. Staveley]59-mrs. staveley did not look as if [she]59-mrs. staveley believed in the good news , for all that . CHAPTER XIV . [HELENA]52-helena 'S DIARY . Indeed , [I]0-i felt lonely all day without [[my]0-i sister]596-my sister . When [I]0-i got [home]258-home , [I]0-i rather hoped that [some friend]898-some friend might have come to see [us]899-us , and have been asked to stay to tea . [The housemaid]900-the housemaid opened the door to [me]0-i . [I]0-i asked [Maria]64-maria if [anybody]3926-anybody had called . " Yes , [miss]4033-miss ; [a lady]210-a lady , to see [the master]4035-the master . "[0-i] " [A stranger]287-a stranger ? "[0-i] " Never saw [her]210-a lady before , [miss]4033-miss , in all [my]0-i life . "[0-i] [I]0-i put no more questions . [Many ladies]902-many ladies visit [[my]0-i father]615-my father . [They]902-many ladies come and go in a sort of secrecy . When [[my]0-i father]615-my father came in to tea , [I]0-i began to feel some curiosity about [the lady who had called on [him]615-my father]908-the lady who had called on him . [I]0-i asked at what time [we]964-we might expect to receive [Miss Jillgall]66-miss jillgall . " [She]66-miss jillgall is staying , [Helena]52-helena , at [a small hotel in [the town]205-the town]4137-a small hotel in the town . [I]0-i have already sent to say that [we]964-we are waiting to see [her]66-miss jillgall . Perhaps [you]963-him will look at [the spare bedroom]4139-the spare bedroom ? "[0-i] " It shall be got ready , [father]3936-father , directly . "[0-i] [I]0-i ran into [the house]314-the house ; [I]0-i rushed [upstairs]3864-upstairs into [the room that is [Eunice]53-eunice 's and [mine]968-mine]967-the room that is eunice 's and mine ; [I]0-i locked the door , and then [I]0-i gave way to [my]0-i rage , before it stifled [me]0-i . [I]0-i stamped on the floor , [I]0-i clinched [my]0-i fists , [I]0-i cast [myself]0-i on the bed , [I]0-i reviled [that hateful woman]969-that hateful woman by every hard word that [I]0-i could throw at [her]969-that hateful woman . Oh , the luxury of it ! the luxury of it ! Cold water and [my]0-i hairbrush soon made [me]0-i fit to be seen again . As for [the spare room]970-the spare room , [it]970-the spare room looked a great deal too comfortable for an incubus from foreign parts . The one improvement that [I]0-i could have made , if [a friend of mine]971-a friend of mine had been expected , was suggested by the window - curtains . [I]0-i was looking at a torn place in one of them , and determined to leave [it]972-it unrepaired , when [I]0-i felt an arm slipped round [my]0-i waist from behind . A voice , so close that it tickled [my]0-i neck , said : " [Dear girl]4141-dear girl , what [friends]3955-friends [we]4143-we shall be ! "[0-i] [I]0-i turned round , and confronted [Miss Jillgall]66-miss jillgall . CHAPTER XV . HELENA 'S DIARY . If [I]0-i am not [a good girl]973-a good girl , where is [a good girl to be found]974-a good girl to be found ? This is in [Eunice]53-eunice 's style . It sometimes amuses [me]0-i to mimic [[my]0-i simple sister]975-my simple sister . [I]0-i have just torn three pages out of [my]0-i diary , in deference to the expression of [[my]0-i father]615-my father 's wishes . [He]615-my father took the first opportunity which [[his]615-my father cousin]945-his cousin permitted [him]615-my father to enjoy of speaking to [me]0-i privately ; and [his]615-my father object was to caution [me]0-i against hastily relying on first impressions of [anybody]3926-anybody - especially of [Miss Jillgall]66-miss jillgall . " Wait for a day or two , "[615-my father] [he]615-my father said ; " and then form [your]0-i estimate of [the new member of [[our]4145-our household]4146-our household]4144-the new member of our household . "[615-my father] The stormy state of [my]0-i temper had passed away , and had left [my]0-i atmosphere calm again . [I]0-i could feel that [I]0-i had received good advice ; but unluckily it reached [me]0-i too late . [I]0-i had formed [my]0-i estimate of [Miss Jillgall]66-miss jillgall , and had put it in writing for [my]0-i own satisfaction , at least an hour before [[my]0-i father]615-my father found [himself]615-my father at liberty to speak to [me]0-i . [I]0-i do n't agree with [him]615-my father in distrusting first impressions ; and [I]0-i had proposed to put [my]0-i opinion to the test , by referring to what [I]0-i had written about [[his]615-my father cousin]945-his cousin at a later time . However , after what [he]615-my father had said to [me]0-i , [I]0-i felt bound in filial duty to take the pages out of [my]0-i book , and to let two days pass before [I]0-i presumed to enjoy the luxury of hating [Miss Jillgall]66-miss jillgall . On one thing [I]0-i am determined : [Eunice]53-eunice shall not form a hasty opinion , either . [She]66-miss jillgall shall undergo the same severe discipline of self - restraint to which [[her]66-miss jillgall sister]544-her sister is obliged to submit . Let [us]982-us be just , as [somebody]983-somebody says , before [we]982-us are generous . No more for to - day . ....... [I]0-i open [my]0-i diary again - after the prescribed interval has elapsed . The first impression produced on [me]0-i by [the new member of [our]982-us household]4144-the new member of our household remains entirely unchanged . Have [I]0-i already made the remark that , when one removes a page from a book , it does not necessarily follow that one destroys the page afterward ? or did [I]0-i leave this to be inferred ? In either case , [my]0-i course of proceeding was the same . [I]0-i ordered some paste to be made . Then [I]0-i unlocked a drawer , and found [my]0-i poor ill - used leaves , and put them back in [my]0-i Journal . An act of justice is surely not the less praiseworthy because it is an act of justice done to [[one]431-one 's self]986-one 's self . [[My]0-i father]615-my father has often told [me]0-i that [he]615-my father revises [his]615-my father writings on religious subjects . [I]0-i may harmlessly imitate that good example , by revising [my]0-i restored entry . It is now a sufficiently remarkable performance to be distinguished by a title . Let [me]0-i call it : Impressions of [Miss Jillgall]66-miss jillgall . [My]0-i first impression was a strong one - it was produced by the state of [this lady]3803-this lady 's breath . In other words , [I]0-i was obliged to let [her]3803-this lady kiss [me]0-i . It is a duty to be considerate toward human infirmity . [I]0-i will only say that [I]0-i thought [I]0-i should have fainted . [My]0-i second impression draws a portrait , and produces a striking likeness . Figure , little and lean - hair of a dirty drab color which [we]989-we see in string - small light gray eyes , sly and restless , and deeply sunk in the head - prominent cheekbones , and a florid complexion - an inquisitive nose , turning up at the end - a large mouth and a servile smile - raw - looking hands , decorated with black mittens - a misfitting white jacket and a limp skirt - manners familiar - temper cleverly hidden - voice too irritating to be mentioned . Whose portrait is this ? It is the portrait of [Miss Jillgall]66-miss jillgall , taken in words . [Her]66-miss jillgall true character is not easy to discover ; [I]0-i suspect that it will only show itself little by little . That [she]66-miss jillgall is [a born meddler in other people]990-a born meddler in other people 's affairs , [I]0-i think [I]0-i can see already . [I]0-i also found out that [she]66-miss jillgall trusted to flattery as the easiest means of making [herself]66-miss jillgall agreeable . [She]66-miss jillgall tried [her]66-miss jillgall first experiment on [myself]0-i . " [[You]0-i charming girl]4147-you charming girl , "[66-miss jillgall] [she]66-miss jillgall began , " [your]0-i bright face encourages [me]66-miss jillgall to ask a favor . Pray make [me]66-miss jillgall useful ! The one aspiration of [my]66-miss jillgall life is to be useful . "[0-i] But here again it was necessary to remember that [this odious person]1010-this odious person was [[my]0-i father]615-my father 's guest . "[0-i] [I]0-i had really not supposed it possible that [she]1010-this odious person could be more unendurable than ever . [Selina]72-selina was more than satisfied ; [she]72-selina was quite delighted . " Is that it , indeed ? An explanation was all [I]72-selina wanted . How good of [you]72-selina ! And now tell [me]72-selina - is there no chance , in [the house]314-the house or out of [the house]314-the house , of [my]72-selina making [myself]72-selina useful ? Oh , what 's that ? Do [I]72-selina see a chance ? [I]72-selina do ! [I]72-selina do ! "[72-selina] [Miss Jillgall]66-miss jillgall 's eyes are more than mortal . At one time , they are microscopes . At another time , they are telescopes . [She]66-miss jillgall discovered right across [the room]3541-the room the torn place in the window - curtain . In an instant , [she]66-miss jillgall snatched a dirty little leather case out of [her]66-miss jillgall pocket , threaded [her]66-miss jillgall needle and began darning the curtain . When [I]0-i heard [her]66-miss jillgall singing voice , [I]0-i became reckless of consequences , and ran out of [the room]3541-the room with [my]0-i hands over [my]0-i ears . CHAPTER XVI . HELENA 'S DIARY . When [I]0-i reached the foot of [the stairs]1016-the stairs , [[my]0-i father]615-my father called [me]0-i into [[his]615-my father study]910-his study . [I]0-i found [him]615-my father at [his]615-my father writing - table , with such a heap of torn - up paper in [his]615-my father waste - basket that it overflowed on to the floor . [He]615-my father explained to [me]0-i that [he]615-my father had been destroying a large accumulation of old letters , and had ended when [his]615-my father employment began to grow wearisome in examining [his]615-my father correspondence rather carelessly . The result was that [he]615-my father had torn up a letter , and a copy of the reply , which ought to have been set aside as worthy of preservation . After collecting the fragments , [he]615-my father had heaped them on the table . If [I]0-i could contrive to put them together again on fair sheets of paper , and fasten them in their right places with gum , [I]0-i should be doing [him]615-my father a service , at a time when [he]615-my father was too busy to set [his]615-my father mistake right for [himself]615-my father . Here was the best excuse that [I]0-i could desire for keeping out of [Miss Jillgall]66-miss jillgall 's way . [I]0-i cheerfully set to work on the restoration of the letters , while [[my]0-i father]615-my father went on with [his]615-my father writing . Having put the fragments together - excepting a few gaps caused by morsels that had been lost - [I]0-i was unwilling to fasten them down with gum , until [I]0-i could feel sure of not having made any mistakes ; especially in regard to some of the lost words which [I]0-i had been obliged to restore by guess - work . So [I]0-i copied the letters , and submitted them , in the first place , to [[my]0-i father]615-my father 's approval . [He]615-my father praised [me]0-i in the prettiest manner for the care that [I]0-i had taken . But , when [he]615-my father began , after some hesitation , to read [my]0-i copy , [I]0-i noticed a change . The smile left [his]615-my father face , and the nervous quiverings showed themselves again . " Quite right , [[my]615-my father child]242-my child , "[615-my father] [he]615-my father said , in low sad tones . On returning to [my]0-i side of the table , [I]0-i expected to see [him]615-my father resume [his]615-my father writing . [He]615-my father crossed [the room]3541-the room to the window and stood with [his]615-my father back to [me]0-i looking out . When [I]0-i had first discovered the sense of the letters , they failed to interest [me]0-i . [A tiresome woman]1022-a tiresome woman , presuming on the kindness of [a good - natured man]1023-a good - natured man to beg a favor which [she]1022-a tiresome woman had no right to ask , and receiving a refusal which [she]1022-a tiresome woman had richly deserved , was no remarkable event in [my]0-i experience as [[my]0-i father]615-my father 's secretary and [copyist]1025-copyist . But the change in [his]615-my father face , while [he]615-my father read the correspondence , altered [my]0-i opinion of the letters . There was more in them evidently than [I]0-i had discovered . [I]0-i kept [my]0-i manuscript copy - here it is : From [Miss Elizabeth Chance]41-elizabeth to [the Rev. Abel Gracedieu]73-the rev. abel gracedieu . Date of year , 1859 . Date of month , missing . " [DEAR SIR]4184-dear sir - [You]4184-dear sir have , [I]1026-i hope , not quite forgotten the interesting conversation that [we]4185-we had last year in [[the Governor]148-the governor 's rooms]4187-the governor 's rooms . [I]1026-i am afraid [I]1026-i spoke a little flippantly at the time ; but [I]1026-i am sure [you]4184-dear sir will believe [me]1026-i when [I]1026-i say that this was out of no want of respect to [yourself]4184-dear sir . [My]1026-i pecuniary position being far from prosperous , [I]1026-i am endeavoring to obtain the vacant situation of housekeeper in a public institution the prospectus of which [I]1026-i inclose . [You]4184-dear sir will see it is a rule of [the place]3869-the place that [a candidate]4189-a candidate must be [a single woman which [I]1026-i am]4190-a single woman which i am , and must be recommended by [a clergyman]329-a clergyman . [You]4184-dear sir are [the only reverend gentleman whom it is]4192-the only reverend gentleman whom it is [my]1026-i good fortune to know , and the thing is of course a mere formality . Pray excuse this application , and oblige [me]1026-i by acting as [my]1026-i reference . "[1026-i] Sincerely [yours]1026-i , " [ELIZABETH CHANCE]41-elizabeth . "[1026-i] " P. S. - Please address : [Miss E. Chance]74-miss e. chance , [Poste Restante]75-poste restante , [St. Martin's - le - Grand]4193-st. martin's - le - grand , [London]3-london . "[1026-i] " From the Rev. [Abel Gracedieu]73-the rev. abel gracedieu to [Miss Chance]41-elizabeth . Copy . "[1026-i] MADAM - The brief conversation to which [your]1026-i letter alludes , took place at an accidental meeting between [us]1027-us . [I]0-i then saw [you]1026-i for the first time , and [I]0-i have not seen [you]1026-i since . It is impossible for [me]0-i to assert the claim of [a perfect stranger]1028-a perfect stranger , like [yourself]1026-i , to fill a situation of trust . [I]0-i must beg to decline acting as [your]1026-i reference . " [[Your]1026-i obedient servant]4194-your obedient servant , "[73-the rev. abel gracedieu] [ABEL GRACEDIEU]73-the rev. abel gracedieu . " ....... [[My]73-the rev. abel gracedieu father]615-my father was still at the window . In that idle position [he]615-my father could hardly complain of [me]73-the rev. abel gracedieu for interrupting [him]615-my father , if [I]73-the rev. abel gracedieu ventured to talk about the letters which [I]73-the rev. abel gracedieu had put together . If [my]73-the rev. abel gracedieu curiosity displeased [him]615-my father , [he]615-my father had only to say so , and there would be an end to any allusions of mine to the subject . [My]73-the rev. abel gracedieu first idea was to join [him]615-my father at the window . On reflection , and still perceiving that [he]615-my father kept [his]615-my father back turned on [me]73-the rev. abel gracedieu , [I]73-the rev. abel gracedieu thought it might be more prudent to remain at the table . "[73-the rev. abel gracedieu] This [Miss Chance]41-elizabeth seems to be [an impudent person]1029-an impudent person ? " [I]41-elizabeth said . "[41-elizabeth] Yes . " Here were three answers which [Eunice]53-eunice [herself]53-eunice would have been quick enough to interpret as three warnings to say no more . TENBRUGGEN]49-mrs. tenbruggen . CHAPTER XVIII . [EUNICE]53-eunice 'S DIARY . Here [I]0-i am , writing [my]0-i history of [myself]0-i , once more , by [my]0-i own bedside . Some unexpected events have happened while [I]0-i have been away . One of them is the absence of [[my]0-i sister]596-my sister . [Helena]52-helena has left [home]258-home on a visit to [a northern town]4248-a northern town by [the seaside]4249-the seaside . [She]52-helena is staying in [the house of]4250-the house of [a minister one of [[papa]58-papa 's friends]4252-papa 's friends]4251-a minister one of papa 's friends , and is occupying a position of dignity in which [I]0-i should certainly lose [my]0-i head . [The minister]161-the minister and [[his]161-the minister wife]174-his wife and [daughters]4255-daughters propose to set up [a Girls ' Scripture Class]4256-a girls ' scripture class , on the plan devised by [papa]3927-papa ; and [they]4258-they are at a loss , [poor helpless people]4259-poor helpless people , to know how to begin . [Helena]52-helena has volunteered to set the thing going . And there [she]52-helena is now , advising [everybody]3957-everybody , governing [everybody]3957-everybody , encouraging [everybody]3957-everybody - issuing directions , finding fault , rewarding merit - oh , [dear]4177-dear , let [me]0-i put it all in one word , and say : thoroughly enjoying [herself]52-helena .
